questions.text: A 70-year-old male undergoes a Transrectal Ultrasound (TRUS) due to elevated PSA levels. Which prostate zone is most commonly associated with prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Prostate Zones and Cancer

  • Prostate Zones:
    • The prostate is divided into peripheral, central, transitional, and anterior fibromuscular zones.
  • Peripheral Zone:
    • The largest zone and the most common site for prostate cancer. Located posteriorly, making it accessible for digital rectal examination (DRE).
  • Central Zone:
    • Surrounds the ejaculatory ducts, less commonly affected by cancer.
  • Transitional Zone:
    • Surrounds the urethra, most commonly affected by BPH.
  • TRUS Use:
    • Important for visualising prostate anatomy, guiding biopsies, and assessing prostate size and abnormalities.

Option A: Peripheral zone is Correct. This is where most prostate cancers originate, accounting for approximately 70-80% of cases.

Option B: Central zone is Incorrect. The central zone is less commonly involved in prostate cancer, representing only about 5-10% of cases.

Option C: Transitional zone is Incorrect. This zone is most commonly associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) rather than prostate cancer.

Option D: Anterior fibromuscular zone is Incorrect. This zone has no glandular tissue and is not typically involved in prostate cancer.

Key Takeaway:

  • The peripheral zone is the primary site for prostate cancer.
  • TRUS is used for imaging the prostate and guiding biopsies.

questions.text: A 65 year old male with elevated PSA and suspicious findings on DRE is scheduled for a prostate biopsy. Which imaging modality is most commonly used to guide the prostate biopsy?
questions.solution:
Prostatic Biopsy and Imaging

Prostatic biopsy is an essential procedure for diagnosing prostate cancer in patients with an elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level or an abnormal digital rectal exam (DRE).

Imaging Guidance

  • Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS): The standard imaging technique for guiding prostate biopsies. It provides real-time visualisation of the prostate and allows for precise needle placement.

Procedure

  • Core samples: Multiple core samples are taken from different regions of the prostate, focusing primarily on the peripheral zone where prostate cancer most commonly occurs.
  • Complications: Bleeding, infection, and urinary symptoms are potential complications after a prostate biopsy.

Biopsy Routes

  • Transrectal: The biopsy needle is inserted through the rectum.Transrectal ultrasound is generally not suitable for sampling the anterior prostate, especially in patients with large prostates.
  • Transperineal: The biopsy needle is inserted through the skin between the scrotum and anus. Transperineal biopsy is becoming increasingly popular as an alternative to conventional transrectal biopsy.

Fusion biopsy combines MRI and TRUS images to provide more accurate targeting of suspicious lesions, improving the detection of prostate cancer.

Option A: MRI is Incorrect. MRI can be used for targeted biopsies but is not the standard firstline imaging for routine prostate biopsies.

Option B: Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) is Correct. TRUS is the standard imaging method for guiding prostate needle biopsies, allowing real time visualisation.

Option C: CT scan is Incorrect. CT is not typically used for guiding prostate biopsies due to lower resolution for soft tissue and higher radiation exposure.

Option D: X Ray is Incorrect. X Ray does not provide sufficient detail for guiding prostate biopsies.

Key Takeaway:

  • TRUS is the standard for guiding prostate biopsies.
  • Multiple core samples are taken to ensure accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: During cystoscopy, a 65 year old male with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) is found to have a prostatic urethra that is elongated and obstructed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Prostatic Urethra and Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH)

Prostatic Urethra is the portion of the urethra that passes through the prostate gland. In a normal individual, it appears as a smooth, wide lumen.

BPH and Prostatic Urethra:

Changes: BPH, a condition where the prostate gland enlarges, leads to an elongated and compressed prostatic urethra due to the increased size of the prostate tissue.

  • Symptoms: BPH often causes lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), including hesitancy, weak stream, straining, and incomplete emptying.
  • Endoscopic Findings: During a cystoscopy, an enlarged prostate can be seen encroaching on the urethra, causing it to become elongated and narrowed.

Management of BPH:

  • Medical therapy: Alpha-blockers and 5-alpha reductase inhibitors are commonly used to manage BPH symptoms.
  • Surgical options: For severe cases, surgical procedures like transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) may be necessary to relieve obstruction and improve urinary flow.

Option A: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is Correct. BPH causes the prostatic urethra to elongate and narrow due to the hyperplastic prostate tissue compressing the urethra.

Option B: Prostate cancer is Incorrect. Although prostate cancer can cause obstruction, it typically presents as a nodular or asymmetric mass rather than uniform urethral elongation and narrowing.

Option C: Urethral stricture is Incorrect. Strictures usually occur in the bulbar or penile urethra, not specifically the prostatic urethra, and they cause localised narrowing rather than elongation.

Option D: Bladder stone is Incorrect. A bladder stone may cause symptoms of obstruction but does not affect the shape or length of the prostatic urethra.

Key Takeaway:

  • BPH typically presents with an elongated, narrowed prostatic urethra on cystoscopy. It's Common cause of lower urinary tract symptoms in older men.

choices.text: PSA levels above 2 ng/mL are always indicative of prostate cancer.
PSA is specific for prostate cancer.
PSA levels can be elevated in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
A normal PSA level rules out prostate cancer.

questions.text: A 70 year old man comes to the clinic for routine screening. He has no urinary symptoms but has a family history of prostate cancer. His digital rectal examination is normal. Which of the following statements about Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA) testing is true?
questions.solution:
ProstateSpecific Antigen (PSA) and Prostate Biopsy

  • PSA (ProstateSpecific Antigen): A protein produced by the prostate gland, often elevated in prostate cancer, BPH, and prostatitis.
  • Normal Range: Typically 04 ng/mL, but age specific ranges may apply. Levels above 4 ng/mL are commonly considered abnormal and warrant further investigation.
  • Screening and Indications: PSA is used to screen for prostate cancer, especially in high risk groups (e.g., men with a family history of prostate cancer, African ancestry). A PSA level > 4 ng/mL or a rapid increase in PSA (velocity > 0.75 ng/mL/year) is concerning and typically leads to further diagnostic steps.
  • Prostate Biopsy: Indicated when PSA is elevated (>4 ng/mL), there is a suspicious digital rectal exam (DRE), or imaging suggests malignancy. TRUS (Transrectal Ultrasound) guided biopsy is the standard method, targeting the peripheral zone where most cancers
  • Other Causes of Elevated PSA: Include BPH, prostatitis, recent ejaculation, urinary retention, and instrumentation (e.g., catheterization).
  • After an infectious episode, it takes 6 weeks to return to baseline.
  • PSA Is artificially lowered, up to two times, in men taking 5α-reductase inhibitors (finasteride, dutasteride).

Option A: PSA levels above 2 ng/mL are always indicative of prostate cancer is incorrect because PSA levels can be elevated due to various conditions, including BPH, prostatitis, and even after certain procedures.

Option B: PSA is prostate specific, not cancer specific. Elevated levels can be due to benign conditions affecting the prostate.

Option C: PSA levels can be elevated in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is Correct because PSA levels may increase with age and conditions such as BPH, inflammation, and infection.

Option D: Normal PSA levels do not rule out prostate cancer, as some prostate cancers may not produce high levels of PSA.

Key Takeaway:

  • Elevated PSA (>4 ng/mL) with family history of prostate cancer should prompt a biopsy.
  • TRUS guided biopsy is the standard approach for prostate cancer diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a minimally invasive surgical approach commonly used for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.solution:
Approaches for Prostate Surgery

  • TURP: Most common for BPH; involves resecting prostate tissue via the urethra.
  • The most common reason for TURP is a combination of severe symptoms and a low flow rate of <12 mL/s.
  • For transurethral resection of the prostate the resectoscope is inserted transurethrally.
  • Electric current is passed through a diathermy loop at the end of the instrument.
  • The surgeon moves this back and forth to create a cavity using diathermy to cauterise as they go.
  • The resultant chips are washed out of the bladder intermittently throughout the procedure.
  • A visual image of the operative field is transmitted through lenses running in the middle of the resectoscope.
  • Around this lens, irrigating fluid is instilled and flows out, washing blood away from the operative field.
  • The procedure is complete when an adequate channel has been created through the prostate.
  • Open Prostatectomy: Used for larger prostates or when TURP is not feasible.
  • Radical Prostatectomy: Complete removal of the prostate, usually for cancer.
  • Laparoscopic and Robotic Surgery: Minimally invasive options for selected cases, offering quicker recovery.
  • Methods of performing prostatectomy The prostate can be approached (1) transurethrally (TURP); (2) retropubically (RPP); (3) through the bladder (transvesical; TVP); or (4) from the perineum

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Open retropubic prostatectomy: Incorrect. This approach is used for larger prostate surgeries or when malignancy is suspected.

Option B. Radical prostatectomy: Incorrect. This is primarily used for prostate cancer treatment, involving complete removal of the prostate.

Option C. Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP): Correct. TURP is the most common minimally invasive surgery for BPH, where excess prostate tissue is removed through the urethra.

Option D. Perineal prostatectomy: Incorrect. This approach involves an incision in the perineum, used mainly for prostate cancer surgery.

Key Points:

  • TURP is the standard minimally invasive procedure for BPH.
  • Radical prostatectomy is used for prostate cancer treatment.

questions.text: What is a common complication associated with prostatectomy?
questions.solution:
Complications of Prostatectomy

  • Urinary Incontinence:
    • Stress incontinence is the most common type, often due to damage to the sphincter muscles or nerves.
    • Urinary leakage may improve over time but can persist, requiring pelvic floor exercises, medications, or further surgery.
  • Retrograde ejaculation or anejaculation.
    • This occurs in about 65-85% of men after prostatectomy.
  • Erectile Dysfunction (ED):
    • Damage to the nerves around the prostate (neurovascular bundles) during surgery can lead to ED.
    • Risk depends on the patient's preoperative function, age, and extent of nerve sparing during surgery.
  • Bladder Neck Contracture:
    • Scar tissue formation at the bladder neck can lead to obstruction and difficulty urinating.
    • May require additional procedures to open the bladder neck.
  • Urethral Stricture:
    • Narrowing of the urethra due to scarring from surgical trauma.
    • Causes obstructive urinary symptoms and may need dilation or urethrotomy.
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs):
    • Risk increases due to catheter use and surgical manipulation of the urinary tract. Treated with antibiotics.
  • Water intoxication
    • Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral resection can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatraemia and haemolysis. Accompanying this, there is frequent confusion and other cerebral events often mimicking a stroke.
  • Less Common Complications:
    • Bleeding
    • Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
    • Anastomotic Leak
    • Chronic Pelvic Pain: Persistent pain in the pelvic area following surgery.
    • Lymphocele:

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Increased risk of colon cancer: Incorrect. Prostatectomy is not associated with an increased risk of colon cancer.

Option B. Erectile dysfunction: Incorrect. Nerve damage during prostatectomy can lead to erectile dysfunction, a common complication. This occurs in about 5-10% of men.

Option C. Chronic kidney disease: Incorrect. Prostatectomy does not directly lead to chronic kidney disease.

Option D. Anejaculation: correct. This occurs in about 65-85% of men after prostatectomy.

Key Points:

Complications of prostatectomy include urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, bladder neck contracture, and UTIs.

choices.text: It is an open surgical procedure.
TURP is the gold standard for treating small bladder stones.
TURP involves resecting prostate tissue using a resectoscope.
It requires a permanent urinary diversion.

questions.text: Which statement about TURP is correct?
questions.solution:
TURP

  • Most common for BPH; involves resecting prostate tissue via the urethra.
  • The most common reason for TURP is a combination of severe symptoms and a low flow rate of <12 mL/s.
  • For transurethral resection of the prostate the resectoscope is inserted transurethrally.
  • Electric current is passed through a diathermy loop at the end of the instrument.
  • The surgeon moves this back and forth to create a cavity using diathermy to cauterise as they go.
  • The resultant chips are washed out of the bladder intermittently throughout the procedure.
  • A visual image of the operative field is transmitted through lenses running in the middle of the resectoscope.
  • Around this lens, irrigating fluid is instilled and flows out, washing blood away from the operative field.
  • The procedure is complete when an adequate channel has been created through the prostate.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. It is an open surgical procedure: Incorrect. TURP is a minimally invasive procedure performed via the urethra.

Option B. TURP is the gold standard for treating small bladder stones: Incorrect. TURP is not used for bladder stones; it is specific to prostate tissue resection.

Option C. TURP involves resecting prostate tissue using a resectoscope: Correct. TURP uses a resectoscope inserted through the urethra to remove excess prostate tissue.

Option D. It requires a permanent urinary diversion: Incorrect. TURP does not require urinary diversion; it maintains normal urinary function.

Key Points:

  • TURP is a minimally invasive procedure to remove prostate tissue.
  • It uses a resectoscope inserted through the urethra.

choices.text: HoLEP is performed through an open surgical incision.
It is specifically designed for treating prostate cancer.
HoLEP is effective for treating large prostates.
It requires longterm catheterization after the procedure.

questions.text: 60-year male was advised prostatectomy. Which of the following statements is true about Holmium Laser Enucleation of the Prostate (HoLEP)?
questions.solution:
Holmium Laser Enucleation of the Prostate (HoLEP)

  • Laser can be used to ablate or vaporise (e.g. green light laser) or enucleate (e.g. HOLEP) the prostate.
  • Photoselective vaporisation of the prostate or green light laser has the advantage that vaporisation is hemostatic and this procedure can be performed even while patients are anticoagulated; however, it is unsuitable for a very large gland.
  • In holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HOLEP),
    • laser is used to cut all the attachments of the adenoma to the false capsule and simultaneously coagulate any of the small vessels crossing the relatively avascular plane between the peripheral and transitional zones of the prostate while the tip of the cystoscope is used, much like the surgeon's finger in Millin's prostatectomy, to enucleate the transitional zone adenoma.
    • The enucleated adenoma is pushed into the bladder, where it is morcellated and extracted via the cystoscope.
    • Damage to the external sphincter is avoided provided the verumontanum is used as a guide to the most distal point of the resection/vaporisation/enucleation.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. HoLEP is performed through an open surgical incision: Incorrect. HoLEP is a minimally invasive procedure performed through the urethra.

Option B. It is specifically designed for treating prostate cancer: Incorrect. HoLEP is used for benign prostatic hyperplasia, not cancer.

Option C. HoLEP is effective for treating large prostates: Correct. HoLEP can enucleate large volumes of prostate tissue effectively.

Option D. It requires long-term catheterization after the procedure: Incorrect. HoLEP typically results in short-term catheter use due to quicker recovery.

Key Points:

  • HoLEP is effective for large prostates.
  • It is a minimally invasive, laser-based procedure.

choices.text: Hyponatremia due to chronic kidney disease

questions.text: A 72 year old male undergoes surgery for benign prostatic hyperplasia. Postoperatively, he develops confusion, headache, nausea, and hypertension. His serum sodium level is found to be 120 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
TURP Syndrome

  • TURP syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), resulting from the absorption of irrigation fluids used during the procedure.
  • Causes:
    • Fluid Absorption: Excessive absorption of hypotonic irrigation fluid into the systemic circulation through open venous sinuses in the prostate.
    • Hyponatremia: Dilutional hyponatremia due to the absorption of large volumes of hypotonic fluid.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Neurological Symptoms: Confusion, headache, restlessness, visual disturbances, seizures, and coma.
    • Cardiovascular Symptoms: Hypertension, bradycardia, arrhythmias, and pulmonary edema.
    • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Nausea and vomiting.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Low serum sodium levels (hyponatremia), low serum osmolality.
    • Electrocardiogram (ECG): May show signs of electrolyte imbalances.
  • Management:
    • Fluid Management: Restrict fluid intake; administer diuretics (e.g., furosemide) to manage fluid overload.
    • Correction of Hyponatremia: Administer hypertonic saline (3%) carefully if symptomatic hyponatremia is present; monitor sodium levels closely.
  • Prevention:
    • Use of isotonic glycine as an irrigation fluid instead of hypotonic solutions.
    • Limiting the duration of the TURP procedure.
    • Monitoring fluid input and output carefully during surgery.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Hyponatremia due to chronic kidney disease: Incorrect. While chronic kidney disease can cause hyponatremia, the acute onset of neurological symptoms immediately following TURP and the context of fluid absorption points more towards TUR syndrome.

Option B. TURP syndrome: Correct. TURP syndrome is characterized by the absorption of hypotonic irrigation fluid during TURP, leading to hyponatremia, hypervolemia, and subsequent neurological and cardiovascular symptoms.

Option C. Postoperative infection: Incorrect. Postoperative infection can cause fever, chills, and malaise, but it does not typically cause acute hyponatremia and the neurological symptoms described.

Option D. Acute urinary retention: Incorrect. Acute urinary retention would present with suprapubic pain, inability to void, and bladder distension, not with hyponatremia and neurological symptoms.

Key Points:

  • TURP syndrome is characterised by hyponatremia, neurological, and cardiovascular symptoms due to the absorption of irrigation fluid during TURP.

questions.text: What is Marion's disease also known as?
questions.solution:
Marion's Disease

  • Bladder Outflow Obstruction Caused by the Bladder Neck
  • Etiology:
    • Muscular Hypertrophy: Thickening of the internal sphincter muscle can lead to obstruction.
    • Fibrosis: Scarring and fibrosis at the bladder neck, often following procedures like TURP or radiotherapy.
    • Bladder Neck Dyssynergia: Dyssynchronous contraction of the bladder neck muscles, also known as functional bladder neck obstruction.
  • Clinical Syndromes:
    • Marion's Disease (Prostatism Sans Prostate): Muscular hypertrophy of the internal sphincter in young individuals can cause complications like vesical diverticulum or hydronephrosis.
    • Symptoms: Similar to those of prostatic enlargement, including urinary frequency, urgency, hesitancy, and weak stream.
  • Treatment:
    • Medications: Alpha-blockers (e.g., alfuzosin, tamsulosin, doxazosin, prazosin) are used to relax the bladder neck and improve urine flow. Side effects may include postural hypotension.
    • Surgical Intervention: Transurethral incision of the bladder neck is the preferred surgical treatment. Recurrence of symptoms may occur if the incision is inadequate.
  • Complications: Development of vesical diverticulum and hydronephrosis due to persistent outflow obstruction.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Chronic prostatitis: Incorrect. Chronic prostatitis is long term inflammation of the prostate.

Option B. Prostatic abscess: Incorrect. A prostatic abscess involves localised pus formation within the prostate due to infection.

Option C. prostatism sans prostate: Correct. Marion's disease refers to prostatism sans prostate.

Option D. Prostatic calculi: Incorrect. Prostatic calculi are stones within the prostate gland.

Key Points:

  • Bladder neck obstruction can result from muscle hypertrophy, fibrosis, or dyssynergic muscle contraction.

questions.text: Corpora amylacea found in the prostate gland are:
questions.solution:
Corpora Amylacea

  • Concentric, laminated bodies found in the prostate and other tissues, composed of glycoproteins and keratin.
  • Significance: Commonly seen in the aging prostate and may increase with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Not typically associated with malignancy.
  • Clinical Relevance: Generally incidental findings, not requiring treatment unless associated with symptoms or complications.
  • PROSTATIC CALCULI
    • Prostatic calculi are of two varieties: endogenous, which are common, and exogenous, which are comparatively rare.
    • An exogenous prostatic calculus is a urinary (commonly ureteric) calculus that becomes arrested in the prostatic urethra.
    • Endogenous prostatic calculi are usually composed of calcium phosphate.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Cancerous nodules: Incorrect. Corpora amylacea are not cancerous but benign structures.

Option B. Calcified stones: Incorrect. While corpora amylacea can calcify, they are primarily composed of proteins and other substances.

Option C. Small proteinaceous bodies: Correct. Corpora amylacea are small, laminated, proteinrich bodies commonly found in the prostate.

Option D. Sites of infection: Incorrect. They are not typically associated with infection but may be present in cases of chronic inflammation.

Key Points:

  • Corpora amylacea are small proteinaceous bodies found in the prostate.
  • They are generally benign and often incidental findings.

questions.text: A prostate cancer patient is found to have a tumour confined to the prostate with a high PSA level and a Gleason score of 8. What stage does this represent?
questions.solution:
Prostate Cancer Staging

  • T1 Stage: Tumors Incidentally Found in a Benign Gland
    • T1a: Tumor involves less than 5% of the prostatectomy specimen; usually well or moderately differentiated.
    • T1b: Tumor involves more than 5% of the prostatectomy specimen.
    • T1c: Tumor is not palpable but detected due to raised PSA levels.
  • T2 Stage: Tumors Confined Within the Prostate Capsule
    • T2a: Tumor involves less than half of one lobe of the prostate.
    • T2b: Tumor involves more than half of one lobe but not both lobes.
    • T2c: Tumor involves both lobes but is still confined within the prostate gland.
  • T3 Stage: Tumors Extending Through the Prostate Capsule
    • T3a: Unilateral or bilateral extension beyond the prostate capsule.
    • T3b: Extension into the seminal vesicles.
  • T4 Stage: Tumors Involving Adjacent Structures Beyond Seminal VesiclesTumor is fixed or invades surrounding structures such as levator muscles, external sphincter, rectum, or pelvic sidewall.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Stage I: Incorrect. Stage I indicates low grade tumours confined to the prostate, typically with a low PSA.

Option B. Stage II: Correct. Stage II includes tumors confined to the prostate but with higher PSA levels or Gleason scores, indicating higher grade.

Option C. Stage III: Incorrect. Stage III involves extension beyond the prostate into surrounding tissues.

Option D. Stage IV: Incorrect. Stage IV indicates distant metastasis or invasion into adjacent organs.

Key Points:

  • Stage II prostate cancer is confined to the prostate but has higher PSA or Gleason scores.

questions.text: 65 year male presents with prostate cancer. Which of the following is considered a standard treatment option for localised prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Prostate Cancer Management

  • Early Disease (T1, T2, Some T3):
    • Curative Treatment: Possible for patients with localized disease.
    • Low-Risk Prostate Cancer: Managed with active surveillance, including regular PSA testing, DRE, mpMRI, and biopsies. About one-third may need radical treatment eventually.
    • Treatment Options: Radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, or active monitoring, depending on patient's age, health status, and preferences.
  • Intermediate-Risk Disease:
    • Treatment in Younger Patients (<70 years): Radical prostatectomy or radiotherapy. Active monitoring remains an option, especially for elderly patients.
    • Elderly Patients with Outflow Obstruction: TURP with or without hormone therapy.
  • High-Risk Disease (Significant Risk of Progression):
    • Multimodal Therapy: Includes early androgen ablation and radiotherapy.
    • Younger Patients (T3 Disease): Combination of androgen ablation, radiotherapy, and possibly surgery (radical prostatectomy with salvage radiotherapy).
  • Advanced Disease (T4, Nodal or Distant Metastases):
    • Palliative Treatment: Androgen ablation as the first line to manage symptoms.
    • Chemotherapy (Docetaxel): Considered for younger, fitter men with metastatic disease.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Watchful waiting: Incorrect. Although used in certain cases, it is not an active treatment but an observation strategy.

Option B. Chemotherapy: Incorrect. Chemotherapy is typically reserved for advanced or metastatic prostate cancer, not localized disease.

Option C. Radical prostatectomy: Correct. Radical prostatectomy is a common treatment for localized prostate cancer, involving complete removal of the prostate.

Option D. Radiotherapy: Incorrect. This alone is not a treatment for prostate cancer.

Key Points:

  • Radical prostatectomy is a standard treatment for localised prostate cancer.
  • Active surveillance is an option for low risk cases.

questions.text: Which imaging modality is most commonly used to detect osseous metastases in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Imaging Techniques for Prostate Cancer

  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):
    • High-Tesla MRI (1.5-3 T): Most accurate for local staging of prostate cancer.
    • mpMRI (Multiparametric MRI): Used preoperatively to assess local stage and pelvic lymph nodes. Useful in active surveillance and detecting recurrent prostate cancer after surgery. However, sensitivity for detecting small capsular spread is limited.
    • Limitations: Low-grade tumors often not visible on MRI and may be clinically insignificant.
  • Transrectal Ultrasound (TRUS):
    • Used for staging prostate cancer, especially to identify locally extensive disease (T2). More sensitive than rectal examination but can still miss many tumors.
    • Combined with PSA testing and DRE, TRUS detects only 30-50% of cancers, missing many compared to breast cancer screening.
  • Bone Scan:
    • Recommended if metastatic spread is suspected (e.g., high PSA >10 ng/mL, advanced disease, Gleason score ≥7).
    • Uses technetium-99m and a gamma camera to detect bone metastases.
    • More sensitive than skeletal surveys but can produce false positives in areas of arthritis, osteomyelitis, or healing fractures.
  • Positron Emission Tomography (PET) Scan:
    • PSMA-PET: Uses gallium-labelled prostate-specific membrane antigen to detect lymph node metastasis and is potentially superior to MRI.
    • Effective in staging before treatment and restaging after treatment relapse.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Computed Tomography (CT) scan: Incorrect. While CT can identify bone metastases, it is less sensitive than bone scans.

Option B. Bone scintigraphy (bone scan): Correct. Bone scans are sensitive for detecting osseous metastases and are commonly used in prostate cancer staging.

Option C. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): Incorrect. MRI is excellent for soft tissue and spinal metastases but is not routinely used for bone metastasis screening.

Option D. Ultrasound: Incorrect. Ultrasound is not effective for detecting bone metastases.

Key Points:

  • mpMRI: Preferred for local staging, surveillance, and detecting recurrence.
  • Bone Scan: Important for detecting bone metastases in high-risk patients.
  • PSMA-PET: Highly sensitive for detecting lymph node metastasis and restaging.

choices.text: The tumor is well differentiated and less aggressive.
The tumor is moderately differentiated with intermediate aggressiveness.
The tumor is poorly differentiated and highly aggressive.
The Gleason score indicates a nonmalignant lesion.

questions.text: A prostate biopsy shows a Gleason score of 7 (3+4). What does this indicate about the tumor?
questions.solution:
Histological Classification and Grading of Prostate Cancer

  • Histological Structure:
    • The prostate is composed of glandular structures with ducts and acini, making most prostate cancers adenocarcinomas. Prostatic glands are surrounded by myoepithelial cells.
    • Early signs of carcinoma include loss of the basement membrane and confluent glandular appearance.
  • Progression and Differentiation:
    • As prostate cancer becomes less differentiated, it forms solid sheets of carcinoma cells.
    • The degree of glandular dedifferentiation and its relation to stroma is classified by the Gleason grading system.
  • Gleason Grading System: based on two most recurring histological pattern
    • Prostate cancer is heterogeneous, with two histological areas scored between 3 and 5.
    • Grades 1 and 2 are no longer reported due to outcomes similar to grade 3.
    • Grade 3 cancers have a low risk of metastasis.Gleason scores are summed to give a total score ranging from 6 to 10, correlating with cancer spread risk and prognosis.
  • ISUP/WHO Simplified Grading System:A simplified grading system with five prognostic grade groups:
    • Grade Group 1: Gleason score 3 + 3 = 6
    • Grade Group 2: Gleason score 3 + 4 = 7
    • Grade Group 3: Gleason score 4 + 3 = 7
    • Grade Group 4: Gleason score 8 (4 + 4, 3 + 5, 5 + 3)
    • Grade Group 5: Gleason score 9 or 10 (4 + 5, 5 + 4, 5 + 5)
    • Higher grade groups indicate a poorer prognosis.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. The tumor is well differentiated and less aggressive: Incorrect. Well Differentiated tumors typically have lower Gleason scores (≤6).

Option B. The tumor is moderately differentiated with intermediate aggressiveness: Correct. A Gleason score of 7 (3+4) indicates moderate differentiation and intermediate risk, often treated more aggressively than lower scores.

Option C. The tumor is poorly differentiated and highly aggressive: Incorrect. Gleason scores of 8-10 are considered poorly differentiated and highly aggressive.

Option D. The Gleason score indicates a non-malignant lesion: Incorrect. A Gleason score is used specifically to grade malignant prostate tumors.

Key Points:

  • Prostate cancer grading is based on histological differentiation, with the Gleason system scoring tissue patterns.
  • Gleason scores range from 6 to 10, with higher scores indicating more aggressive cancer and a higher likelihood of spread.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is diagnosed with a prostatic abscess. What is the primary treatment approach?
questions.solution:
Prostatic Abscess

  • A collection of pus within the prostate, usually due to bacterial infection.
  • Symptoms: Fever, perineal pain, urinary retention, dysuria.
    • Severe, unremitting perineal and rectal pain with occasional tenesmus often cause the condition to be confused with an anorectal abscess. Nevertheless, if a rectal examination is performed, the prostate will be felt to be enlarged, hot, extremely tender and perhaps fluctuant.
    • Retention of urine is likely to occur and, in such men, suprapubic catheterisation is best.
  • Diagnosis: Digital rectal examination, transrectal ultrasound, or CT scan to confirm abscess.
  • Management:
    • The abscess should be drained without delay by transurethral resection (unroofing the whole cavity) or using a needle via the transrectal or perineal
    • Injectable antibiotics such as aminoglycoside or a third-generation cephalosporin is often required for a week.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Oral antibiotics alone: Incorrect. Antibiotics are often necessary, but drainage is required for abscess resolution.

Option B. Percutaneous drainage: Correct. This approach allows for effective drainage of the abscess, combined with antibiotics for infection control.

Option C. Radical prostatectomy: Incorrect. This is not indicated for abscess management; it is used for prostate cancer treatment.

Option D. Watchful waiting: Incorrect. Active intervention is needed to prevent complications from the abscess.
